prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author of the "WIBTA" post is in the wrong. So first, I need to understand the situation.

The author's girlfriend came to live with him after a fight with her parents. He made it clear it was temporary. Then she started bringing her friend over. The author notices that his girlfriend acts differently when her friend is around—nasty and catty. There were specific incidents: when he came home, they laughed at him, and when he offered to make snacks, the friend rudely shut him down. The last straw was when he asked them to move to the bedroom, and they both complained about him even with the TV on. Now he wants to tell her not to bring the friend anymore and push her to reconcile with her parents.

So the question is whether the author is in the wrong. The options are A (yes) or B (no). I need to analyze the situation from both sides.

First, the author's perspective: he's a guest in his own apartment. He's stressed because his girlfriend's friend is making the environment unpleasant. He's not against the friend entirely, since he's met her before and found her okay. But the friend and his girlfriend together create tension. He's had specific instances where he felt mocked and disrespected. His intention is to set boundaries to protect his living space and maybe encourage the reconciliation between the girlfriend and her parents.

On the other hand, the girlfriend's side: she might feel that her friend is a source of support during a difficult time. Maybe she's trying to cope with family issues and the friend is a comfort. The friend's behavior could be unintentional or a reaction to the girlfriend's stress. The girlfriend might perceive the author's request as controlling or not supportive.

But the key points here are about respecting boundaries. The author's apartment is his personal space, and he has the right to set rules about who can be there. The girlfriend's friend has been disrespectful, and the girlfriend's behavior changes significantly when the friend is present. The author has tried to handle it by moving to another room but is now at a breaking point.

The author isn't forbidding his girlfriend from seeing her friend altogether; he's just asking her not to bring the friend to his apartment. That seems reasonable, especially after the negative experiences. Also, pushing her to reconcile with her parents might be necessary if the temporary stay is becoming a long-term issue without resolution.

But is there a chance the author is being too controlling? Maybe if he hadn't communicated his discomfort earlier, but in the post, he mentions specific incidents where the friend was rude. The friend's remarks, like "shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it," are clearly condescending. The girlfriend's defensiveness might indicate she's becoming more sensitive or influenced by her friend's negativity.

In relationships, communication is key. The author is planning to talk to his girlfriend, which is the right approach. But the question is about being "in the wrong." If the friend's presence is causing persistent conflict and disrespect in his home, the author isn't wrong to set boundaries. He's not restricting her social life entirely; just the location. Unless he's being unreasonable without valid cause, but the examples given do support his concerns.

So the answer would be B (No, the author is not in the wrong) because he's protecting his space from disrespectful behavior and addressing the issue after trying to accommodate. The girlfriend's friend's actions are contributing to the problem, and the author has a right to ask for a change.
